title: Behind the wall at Tampa International Airport's construction project
text: Behind the wall at Tampa International Airport's construction project Sep 2, 2015, 2:10pm EDT U.S. Rep. David Jolly, Tampa International Airport Board Chairman Robert Watkins, U.S. Rep. Kathy Castor and TIA CEO Joe Lopano on the construction site between airsides A and C discuss the airport's renovation. Nola Laleye The new entrypoint for passengers coming from airsides A and C on the tram will be between restaurants with covered outdoor seating. Nola Laleye This space closest to Airside C, TIA's busiest airside with Southwest Airlines, will be the Hard Rock Café's first airport location in North America. That space is being designed by Tampa architect Alberto Alfonso. Nola Laleye A look at what will be outdoor seating between where the tram will drop off incoming passengers and the airport terminal. Nola Laleye Legislators say they need Washington to remove caps on the passenger facilities charge so that the local airport boards can decide how much money gets charged and how it is spent on infrastructure. Nola Laleye On the same terrace, but closer to Airside A, a new PF Chang's with outdoor seating will go here. Nola Laleye A combination of covered and uncovered areas on the terrace will show off what many come to Tampa for – the sunshine. Nola Laleye Modernizing Tampa International Airport is tricky since it already is considered a favorite among passengers. Airport officials say they are working hard not to let the project take away any of the things that make it easy and convenient. Nola Laleye U.S. Rep. David Jolly talks to Skanska employees on site at Tampa International Airport on Wednesday. Nola Laleye About 100 local companies are involved in the renovation and expansion project at TIA. Nola Laleye Tampa International Airport Board Chairman Robert Watkins, U.S. Rep. David Jolly, TIA CEO Joe Lopano and U.S. Rep. Kathy Castor share with the media their plans for funding the next two phases of TIA's expansion and renovation. "Research shows that people are willing to pay to keep the airport modern," Lopano said. Nola Laleye "The greatest hurdle to growth and expansion at the Tampa airport is the federal government," U.S. Rep. David Jolly explains. Nola Laleye
